title: The Chamber of Labour elections | AK Wahl
text:
Author: Ilya Tishchenko
The Chamber of Labour1,2 (I’ll use sometimes later AK abbreviation for Arbeiterkammer) represents workers in Austria. It is quite a unique organisation without the analogs in other European countries3. In 2024 there is elections, various dates in various regions, in Tirol and Voralberg they are already over. And that is a rare occasion where I, as non-citizen, can vote, so I become curious.
I’ve took and cleaned up the data and build a few graphs to answer the questions I have AK elections. How in general is turnout? Below I compare it to turnout on parliament elections, the latter is quite impressive on it’s own.
As Oberhuber, F. et. al., 2014 mention this kind of second order elections are in general has lower turnout.

Without digging into the graph who do you think most common winner for such a chamber? Just pause a bit and think - I bet you thought socialist. It’s socialist structure, supposed to protect workers. Yes, overall always socialists won the leadership in AK. Here comes my second question out of curiosity. How it correlates with parliament elections?

As could be seen only socialists (SPÖ4) has a gap downwards, result in parliament always lower than in AK elections. From last elections in 2019 the gap between results in AK (60%) and parliament (21%) is the biggest. For ÖVP the gap sometimes is really small and volatile, starting from 90s. FPÖ gap is growing lately with their increased popularity in parliament.
The open, rather ritorical question I have is if everybody elects socialist to protect himself as an employee why people vote for other during parliament elections?
